characters: INT RINK LOBBY / EXT PARKING LOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pile of COMIC BOOKS are on a shelf next to myriad  others. The most prominent one is called BLUNTMAN AND  CHRONIC'.  A hand reaches in and pulls one out of frame. HOLDEN opens the comic and flips through it He shakes his head.  BANKY looks over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Felt Like this fucking day would never  come.  Issue two - on the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yippee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't start, alright!  This is a cool  moment, and I'd appreciate you not  trying to ruin it.  How often does                 a guy get the opportunity to purchase  something with his name on it! (points to name on cover) Banky Edwards- right! (points to the other) Holden McNeil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, sour puss.  We got the rest of  our lives to be artists.  But it's  supply and demand.  And right now,                 the unwashed masses demand this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off comic) This is easy, alright!  And right now  it pays the bills.  Just don't forget  that we're better than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you who we're better than:  these two fags right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the counter, where STEVE-DAVE, the store  manager, and WALT the Fan-boy, play a card game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lays books on the counter) Alright Old-Maid's - take a break from  the Crazy-8's marathon and ring us up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Well, well,well, Walt Did you see who  it is!  The local celebrities.  Quick -  get them to autograph one of their  books so we can sell it for triple  it's value.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that in need of fifteen cents  right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They snicker and high-five one another.  Holden rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys operate the smallest, ladies'  bridge circle I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your information, we're playing  Crimson Mystical Mages' - an  overpower card game. Not that either  of you would give a shit about  something as advanced        as this -  there are no dick or poopie jokes  involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Holden) I don't think they're fans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we're not.  You're both a couple  of fucking no talents that got lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And obviously your handlers or hangers- on convinced you that your first comic  was good which it was not it was  thoroughly mediocre with a few spiky  bits of dialogue.  And when you get  your foot in the door of the business,  what do you do!  You turn out a piece  of shit like Bluntman and Chronic'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him, Steve-Dave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off comic) Bluntman and Chronic'.  Pah.   What was that thing the little stoner  pulled on the villain in the last  issue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stinky-palm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stinky-palm.  You give comics a bad  name I tell all my customers not to  buy it, to spend their money on a real  comic book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking one hit wonder, dime-store  Frank Miller's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the reality at Comic-Toast -  you're not going to get your ass  kissed here, because both me and Walt  think you suck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steve-Dave offers the boys his two middle fingers, then  goes back to playing his game with Walt.  Holden and  Banky stare, shocked.  Banky nudges Holden and they both  exit Steve-Dave and the Fan-boy slap hands and go back to playing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a dragon card - forty power- ups and twelve life points!  Ha!  I  get your elf card!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're such a bitch!  But thankfully,  I've saved a dark forces Shaman card  for just such an occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suck!  Eighty six life-power  points to my twenty two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I schooled their asses, now I'm  schooling your's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly.  A trash can crashes through the front window.  Steve-Dave and Walt hit the deck like bitches, covering  one another.  They look up slowly. Steve-Dave leaps to  his feet and looks at the shattered mess.  He pulls  something off the garbage can and reads it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it was those two fucks!   Let's call the cops and have them  busted!  I know where their studio is!   Or better yet, let's sue!  You can sue  them, Steve-Dave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still reading note) That won't be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!  Why the hell not!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up check) Because this is a check for three  times what that window cost. (reading note) Dear critics - thanks for the  insight. But like my grandmother  always said - Fuck 'em if they can't  take a joke.. and break their window.'   Kiss it,                Banky the Hack.  P.S. - Your card game blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said Kiss it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A physically large FAN - sweaty brow, tote bag bursting  with comics - leans forward, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could you sign it To a really big  fan!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden sits at a table.  Across from the barely-managing- to-stand Fan.  He offers him a patronizingly kind, half- smile in return,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at a Comic Book show, specifically at a book- signing. Behind Holden hangs a large banner, heralding  HOLDEN McNEIL AND BANKY EDWARDS - CREATORS OF BLUNTMAN AND CHRONIC'. Beside it is a large  mock-up of the comic book cover which features two stoner super-heroes who bear a striking resemblance to a pair of very familiar friendly  neighborhood drug dealers, Holden hands the book back to the Fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love this book man!  This shit's  awesome.  I wish I was like these guys  - getting stoned, talking all raw  about                chicks and fighting  supervillains!  I love these guys!   They're like Cheech and Chong' meet  Bill and fed'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to chink of them as  Rosencrantz and Guildenstern' meet  Vladimir and Estragon'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! (beat) Who!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BANKY signs the book of another COLLECTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you draw this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (signing the comic) I ink it and I'm also the colorist.   The guy next to me draws it.  But we  both came up with the characters,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that mean - you ink it'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  It means that Holden draws the  pictures in pencil, and then he gives  it to me to go over in ink

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you just trace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky freezes up.  He composes himself and continues  signing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not tracing.  I add depth and  shading to give the image mere  definition. Only then does the drawing         really take shape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go over what he draws with a pen -  that's tracing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands book back to  Collector) Not really. (calling out) Next!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LITTLE KID steps up but the Collector lingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man.  If somebody draws something  and then you draw the same thing right  on top of it, not going out-side the  designated original art what do call  that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I don't know.  Tracing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Banky) See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not tracing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Little Kid) Do you want Lour book signed or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - don't get all testy with him  just because you have a problem with  your station in life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm secure with what I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then say it - you're a tracer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing Little Kid's book) How should I sign this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs book back) I don't want you to sign it, I want  the guy that draws Bluntman and  Chronic to sign it.  You're just a  tracer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him, Little Shaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden accepts a comic from another Fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off comic) Who do I sign it to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Holden can finish, a loud crash is heard.  He  looks to his left and freaks. Banky is throttling the Collector from across the table.  The Collector attempts to fight him off.  SECURITY GUARDS pull them apart. Holden grabs Banky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  All I did was call him a  tracer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Collector) I'LL TRACE A CHALK LINE AROUND YOUR  DEAD FUCKING BODY, YOU FUCK?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Security Guard) Could you get him out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Security Guards drag the collector away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a sec!  He jumped me!  And  you're dragging me away!! (exiting) Fucking tracer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling OC) YOUR MOTHER'S A TRACER!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I explain the audience principle  to you!  If you insult and accost  them, then we have no audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He started it!  Fucking cock-knocker!  He's lucky I didn't put my pen through  his thorax!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need I remind you... (holds up watch) Curtain's in ten minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOOPER fills the frame.  He comes off like a typical, pro black/anti-white homeboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For years in this industry whenever an  African-American character - hero or  villain - was introduced usually by  white artists and writers - they got  slapped with racist names that singled  them out as negroes: Black Panther,  Black Lightning, Black Goliath, Black         Mantra, Black Talon, Black Spider,  Black Hand, Black Falcon, Black Cat..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is? (beat) Well bust this - regardless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're at a panel discussion.  The room is full.  Five  creators sit at a long table, their names on placards in  front of them.   (One of them is a very striking Girl.)  The banner behind them reads WORDS UP - MINORITY VOICES IN COMICS'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holds up comic) Now my book, White-Hating Coon',  doesn't have any of that bullshit. The  hero's name is Maleekwa, and he's a         descendant of the black tribe that  established the first society on the  planet, while all you European mother         fuckers were still hiding in caves and  shit, all terrified of the sun. He's a  strong role model that a young black         reader can look up to, Cause I'm here  to tell you - the chickens are comin'  home to roost, ya'll: the black man's         no longer gonna play the minstrel in  the medium of comics and Sci- Fi/Fantasy!  We're keeping it real,  and we're gonna get respect -  by any means necessary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the speech, Holden and Banky enter and sit up  front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out) Bullshit!  Lando Calrissian was a  black man, and he got to fly the  Millennium Falcon!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper whips his head around, looking for the source of  the comment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who said that?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (standing) I did!  Lando Calrissian is a positive  black role model in the realm of  Science Fiction/Fantasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck Lando Calrissian!  Uncle Tom  nigger!  Always some white boy gotta  invoke the holy trilogy'! Bust this -  those movies are about how the white  man keeps the brother man down - even  in a galaxy far, far away.  Check                 this shit.  You got cracker farm-boy  Luke Skywalker, Nazi poster boy -  blond hair, blue eyes.   And then you've got                Darth  Vader: the blackest brother in the  galaxy.  Nubian God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Nubian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up!  Now Vader, he's a  spiritual brother, with the force and  all that shit.  Then this cracker  Skywalker gets his hands on a light- saber, and the boy decides he's                 gonna run the fucking universe - gets  a whole Klan of whites together, and  they're gonna bust up Vader's hood                 the Death Star.  Now what the fuck do  you call that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intergalactic Civil War!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentrification.  They're gonna drive  our the black element, to make the  galaxy quote, unquote safe' for white  folks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Vader turns, out to be Luke's  father.  And in Jedi, they become  friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me bust a cap in your ass,  yo!  Jedi's the most insulting  installment, because Vader's  beautiful,                black visage is  sullied when he pulls off his mask to  reveal a feeble, crusty white man!  They're trying to tell us that deep  inside, we all want to be white!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well isn't that true!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper explodes, He pulls a nine millimeter from his  belt, draws on Banky and fires.  Banky goes down, falling forward into the crowd The crowd screams and starts to  scatter, Hooper jumps over the table and raises his fists in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLACK RAGE! BLACK RAGE!!  I'LL KILL  ANY WHITE FOLKS I LAY MY MOTHER  FUCKIN' EYES ON!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd-is gone.  Holden sits in his chair, laughing.  Hooper steps off the stage and picks Banky's head up off  the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breaking character) What's a Nubian!'  Bitch, you almost  made me laugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper sounds different Actually, he sounds gay.   Actually - he is.  Banky smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what about you!  You didn't tell  me you were going to scream Black  Rage'.  I nearly pissed myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you manage to get away with  this all the time?  Shouldn't cops be  busting your head open right about  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrong coast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off gun) Well this right here - she full of  blanks, okay.  And Opiate gets all  sorts of legal clearances before I go  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your publisher condones these  theatrics!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Condones?  Honey, they insist.  I need  to sell the image to sell the book  Would the audience still buy the  Black Rage' angle if they found out  the book was written by a.. a...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Faggot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you say if it sounds so sexy... (he kisses Banky full on the  lips)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wipes his lips) Hey, hey!  I'll play your victim, but  not your catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it that you sound like Minister  Farakhan when you're on stage..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turn to see... A beautiful, blonde, ruffled-haired angel swinging her  purse in a circle. Her name is ALYSSA.  She's the  striking Girl from the panel who didn't get to say much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and the King of Pop when you're  nor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look out, boys - this kitten has a  whip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoves and slaps him) Always before I get to speak!  I swear  - the next con I attend and they ask  me to be on the minority panel, if I  see your name anywhere near the List,  I'm passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defending himself) Holden.  Banky - this pile of P.M.S.  is Alyssa Jones.  She does that book  Idiosyncratic Routine'.  This is the  fourth panel we've been on together,  and even though she knows my publisher  sets this up and pays for the event.  She still gets mad when it ends with  my act.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wish I was the one who gets to  shoot you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what my father said when I came  - nay - leapt out of the closet (off guys) These boys do Bluntman and Chronic',  which outsells both of our books put  together, hence they're never on a  panel with the likes of us.  They  slumming right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've read your book.  It's cute.   Chick stuff, but cute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoots him a look; to  Alyssa) Sorry about him.  He's dealing with  being an inker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Banky) Oh. You trace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky seethes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking her hand) I really enjoy your book I'm surprised  we've never met at any other Con's  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lose the dick or change your skin tone  and we can get to know each other on  panel after panel while the Pink Black  Panther here plays Chuck D. for the  fanboys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, jealousy. (to the Boys) I told Alyssa I'd buy her a post-rave  drink.  Do the Garden-Staters have to  sprint to the Lincoln Tunnel, or can  you stay for a round in the big, scary  city!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna take off soon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky offers Holden a puzzled glance.  Then he nods to  Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go.

dialogues.speaker: INT BAR
dialogues.text: Holden, Banky, Alyssa and Hooper sir around a table  drinking, talking, and smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie, alright!  Archie and the  Riverdale gang were a pure and fun- lovin' bunch.  You can't find  dysfunction in those comics, because  they were just flat out wholesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Archie and Jughead were lovers. (sips his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.  Archie was the bitch and  Jughead was the butch - that's why  Jughead wears that crown-looking hat  all the time: he the king, of queen  Archie's world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I feel a hate-crime coming on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a point.  Archie never did  settle on Betty or Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he wanted them both at the  same time, you assholes!  He never  chose one because he was trying to get  both of them into a three-way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out a dollar and hands  it to Banky) Here.  I want you to go down to the  corner store and buy yourself a clue.  Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eat it.  Urkel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you to watch it with that Urkel  shit.  Face it, girl - Archie's a  sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up; to Hooper) That's it.  You.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are marching back across the  street with me, and we're going to  pick up a shit load of Archie books, I  am going to prove to you - beyond the  shadow of a doubt that Archie was all  about pussy.  Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sliding out of booth) This boy is conflicted, I shall play  mother-therapist for him.  You two sit  tight.  We shall return promptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky and Hooper exit, leaving Alyssa and Holden alone at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he always Like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For years now.  Started back in third  grade - a nun was teaching us about  the Blessed Trinity.  She's going on  about the three persons in one God  thing - Father, Son, Holy Spirit - and  he just goes ballistic.  I guess it  was too big for him to grasp.  They  got into this huge fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.  How bad could it have been!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever seen a nun call a small child  a fucking cunt-rag'?  Wasn't pretty,  Shit like that's bound to happen when  you make a kid wear a matching tie and  slacks everyday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your parochial school  misadventures!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Limited to wine-tasting prior to mass.  Turned me into a grade school  alcoholic altar boy.  I couldn't tell  you how many mornings after serous  benders                I'd wake up next  to strange priests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you the sharp wit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp!  No.  I'm just a fan of clergy- molestation humor.  Probably why the  extended family quit inviting me to  First Communion parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa laughs.  Holden smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking OC) You play darts!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not professionally.  You know - only  in bars.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DART BOARD
dialogues.text: A dart hits the board then, one hits the wall beside the  board. Alyssa winds up with another dart.  Holden watches. Her's always hit. His never do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your new book seems to be selling  like mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes back to something my  grandmother told me when I was a kid.  "Holden," she said "The big bucks are  in dick and fart jokes."  She was a  church-goer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh - the cry from the heart of a  real artist trapped in commercial hell  - pitying his good fortune.  I'm sure  you can dry your eyes on all those fat  checks you rake in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - did I detect a note of  bitter envy in there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  I'm happy my stuff gets read at  all.  There's very little market for  hearts and flowers in this spandex- clad, big pecs, big tits, big guns  field.  If I sell two issues, I feel  like John Grisham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out window) It's all about marketing.  Over- or  underweight guys who don't get laid -  they're our bread and butter.  People  like those two outside should be  yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, we see a COUPLE making out on the  hood of a car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And sadly, there are more of our core  audience out there than yours. (smiles) Look at that, though - kind of gives  you a little charge, to see two people  in love.  And all over Banky's car, no  less.  That car's seeing more action  right now than it's seen in years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bubbly guy like that, it's hard to  figure out why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking at OC Couple) You've gotta respect that kind of  display of affection.  It's crazy,  rude, self-absorbed - but it's love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Says you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That out there!  That's fleeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fleeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.  You wanna hear about love!   Oh, I'll tell you about love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The story.  The original love story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Doctor Zhivago'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.  My mother's uncle.  He was a  millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kid you not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All through high school, he dated this  one girl.  They  were inseparable.   And when they graduated, she went off  to Carnegie Mellon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Pittsburgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm impressed.  So he stays in the  home town, and they begin their long- distance relationship.  The plan is,  on the  third Sunday of every month,  he'll train out, spend a week then  train back They do this for four  years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not nearly finished.  Two months  before she's going to graduate, he's  got this job digging graves, and he  comes across...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stiff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A steamer trunk containing silver  ingots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many, many silver ingots.  Now, my  mother's uncle being quite the  ingenious chap - he buries the trunk   again and heads up to the main office,  where he proceeds to purchase a  cemetery plot.  Guess which one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So now he owns the plot and all of its  contents.  Two  days later, my  mother's uncle is worth three million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At which time he marries the high  school sweetheart and lives happily  ever after.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not even close.  Inside the steamer  trunk, stenciled into the wood, or  something like that, is a curse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone wrote 'Fuck' inside his new  steamer trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that kind of curse.  A cryptic  curse "Great fortune means great loss"  it said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of asshole writes that  inside a steamer trunk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same kind of asshole that buries  silver ingots.  The day my mother's  uncle is heading out to see the girl,  he stops at his accountant's to grab  some cash, and winds up missing his  train.  So he has to take the next one  - which he does - and he gets there an  hour later than his usual time of  arrival, whereupon he sees lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hero's welcome for the new  millionaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems that while she was standing  on the platform waiting that extra  hour for my mother's uncle to show up,  the girl was dragged into the bushes  by an unknown assailant, raped and  gutted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden is silent Alyssa downs her drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assailant was never apprehended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) That's a love story!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, and here's why: my mother's uncle  rode that train every day for the rest  of his life.  One day up, the next day  back.  Did that 'till the day he died.   He donated the fortune he'd acquired  to the train station in Pittsburgh, to  have a well-lit terminal built.   The train line let him ride for free  after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should hope so.  Jesus, that's the  saddest tale I've ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my love story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa tosses her last dart.  Holden seems a bit dazed.   He looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those two aren't on the hood of  Banky's car anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you It wasn't love. (grabs her purse) I gotta split.  It was really nice  meeting you.  I wish you the best of  luck with your book. (shakes his hand) Tell Hooper I'll call him later.  And  tell your friend to calm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa exits to the night.  Holden stares after her.  Two beats later, Hooper and Banky enter, holding an  'Everything's Archie' comic between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're insane.  Archie is not fucking  Mister Weatherbee!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deny, deny, deny. (to Holden) Where's Alyssa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh!  Oh.  She left.  She said she'd  call you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off comic) He's just offering to help Archie with  his homework!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Read between the lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shoves book at him) Fuck this. (to Holden) Let's go.  Traffic. (no response from Holden) Holden!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaken) What!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out window) D'jou see that dent in the hood of  your car!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out window) What the...!  Son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky runs out Holden shrugs at Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me guess: you like her!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Alyssa Jones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as that's all. (finishes drink) Maybe you can convince that partner of  your's to drop me off downtown before  you scurry out the tunnel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Mister Weatherbee wasn't really trying  to fuck Archie, was he!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They begin exiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell no.  Weatherbee was Reggie's  bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in Holden and Banky's studio/apartment.  It's a  rented loft-style place with high ceilings, wood floors  and sparse furnishings.  There are posters on the walls,  a sort of kitchenette, a hockey net, a big TV. (with all  the trimmings - VCR, Laserdisc player, Sega, SNES), a  huge comfy couch, and two drawing boards with adjacent  desks (littered with pencils, pens, coloring pencils,  paints, erasers, etc.) - at which sit Holden and Banky.   They're working.  Some music plays. C.U. OF HOLDEN PENCILING - over his shoulder, we see  Holden sketching Chronic in mid-attack of his arch- nemesis - the Giggler.  Holden erases a line and re- draws. C.U. OF BANKY INKING - over his shoulder, we see Banky  outlining a pre-penciled page.  He traces Bluntman  swinging from a street light. The two work in silence.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not looking up) This is one of the best street lights  you've ever drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the one across from the post  office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks just like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (beat) What do you wanna do tonight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a pizza.  Watch 'Degrassi Junior  High'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (erases) You got a weird thing for Canadian  melodrama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a weird thing for girls who  say 'aboot'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone starts ringing.  Holden answers it, while still drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank-Hold-Up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROSSCUT between Holden and Hooper.  He's on a phone in a CLUB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper here.  Listen, I know how you  burb-fiends hate the city, but there's  a club shindig going down that I think  you'd get into.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Place called Her-sterectomy - I'm  tempting as bar-keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, Hoop.  We're prepping  the next issue, and we've got our big  M-TV meeting in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her you wouldn't be interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa from last night Alyssa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you begin and end a question  with the same word like that?  You got  skill.  Yes, that one.  She asked me  to invite you.  Now here's the part  where you say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought so.  Ten o'clock.  Later. (both hang up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper.  He invited me to a club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's that faggot going to learn -  you like chicks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Not that kind of a club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when we leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'We'?  You can't go.  He's setting me  up with Alyssa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't want you messing it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I care about your shit.  Maybe  I'll hook up myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling on coat) I just told you - it's not that kind  of club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does one man get to be so funny!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (throws him his coat) How are you going to get home if I  hook up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like that'll happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me explain something to you, my  witless chum the other night in that  bar, we two - Alyssa and I shared a  moment, alright!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you had a moment!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (brings his two pointer  fingers together) We shared a moment.  And in that  moment, one thing was made abundantly  clear: this girl loves me, my friend.    Loves-me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a club - people are mingling, a band is playing,  it's loud.  But something's fishy.  Hooper's tending bar. He hands a GUY a drink.  The Guy sips it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so watered down.  It's  terrible.  Why is it you can never get  a decent drink in these places!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper looks around in a very exaggerated fashion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trying to find you a tissue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guy shoots Hooper an angry glare, Banky enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright - bring on the free hootch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you don't bitch about how  little alcohol is in the drink. (hands Banky a drink; to Guy) You owe me five sixty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Banky) And I suppose you're going to make  your friend here pay for his drink  right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I befriended a guy in a position  of authority so I could abuse that  authority and get free shit.  You want  to do the same?  There's a lonely  Hindu works at the'7-ll' across the  street.  Get in tight with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guy angrily pulls out his money and slams it on the  bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work at that '7-11'! (storms away)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) Wanna be friends!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your better half!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking a piss.  Guy's got a bladder  like an infant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's funny - he says you're hung  like an infant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must his mother tell him everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you do - fall in love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DANCE FLOOR - in the middle of a thrall of people dances Alyssa.  She moves like a cat and she's looking  very sexy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been dancin' for an hour.  Hasn't  stopped yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooper, Holden, and Banky stare OC.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She ain't no Denny Terrio, I'll say  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden smacks Banky and moves to exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. wait, wait - there's something  you should know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got a boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.. no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden exits; They watch him go.  Banky looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There're a lot of chicks in this  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Chicks'.  You're such a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) He didn't really say that about my  dick, did he!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE DANCE FLOOR - Holden slips into the crowd and  dances up to Alyssa.  He intentionally bumps into her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fake rage, dancing) Hey, hey, hey - you fucked up my  cabbage-patch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well - Bluntman himself.   Or should I call you Chronic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me flattered.  I heard you sent  me the invite to this little soiree'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a former home-town girl, to  Mister Home-Town himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying you're from the 'burbs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middletown, N.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here!  I'm from Highlands!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Hooper told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is it that we never ran into one  another?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You graduate from Hudson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Eighty eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went to North.  Also eighty eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a small fucking world.  So you  know the tri-town area!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiz me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miller Hill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wrote my name on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandy Hook?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lost my virginity there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so cool.  The mall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eden Prairie of Menlo Park!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait - here's the big test: Quick  Stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My best friend fucked a dead guy in  the back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that girl!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.  Before she was committed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what this is!  This is fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regarding her move) No, this is the 'Rog'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was talking about us meeting - what  are the chances!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty slim.  I haven't been back to  the 'burbs since my friend's funeral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Quick Stop girl died!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another friend - Julie Dwyer.  She  died in the..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y.M.C.A pool!  Damn!  You knew her  too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One friend in an asylum, the other  friend in the grave.  You're a  dangerous person to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can tap. (does an impromptu tap dance) That was the Buffalo Two-Step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what six years of tap lessons  yields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two towns away from each other for  years and we had to meet in New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Sand stops playing. People clap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coulda been worse - we could have not  met at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.  Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SINGER on stage speaks into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long time ago, we used to have this  bass player who took off one day to  draw funny books or something.  Maybe  you've seen her stuff - it's called  'Idiosyncratic Routine''

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd applauds.  Alyssa shakes her head, smiling.  Holden pokes her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what a lot of people don't know is  that she used to harbor these  delusions that she could sing.  And  she used to subject us to these  throaty renditions of Debbie Gibson  tunes and shit, insisting that we let  her front on a few numbers.  Well, we  didn't and she quit.. and then she got  famous, the bitch. (crowd laughs) But she's here tonight, and I think if  we all begged, or maybe offered her  some X, she'd get up here and treat us  to some of her vocal stylings. (crowd applauds) What do you say, Alyssa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa shakes her head no.  The crowd urges her.  Holden  pushes her forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's shy. (yelling) GET UP HERE AND SING, BITCH!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd thunders.  Alyssa offers the Singer an  embarrassed half-smile.  She looks at Holden, who claps  along with the others and nods toward the stage.  Alyssa  shakes her head and relents, heading through the crowd Banky and Hooper stand at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so queer. (he exits)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You don't know the half of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa jumps on stage, hugging the Singer.  She takes the mic, shaking her head.  The crowd is applauding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is such a twat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers.  Alyssa laughs.  She turns to the band  and says something which they nod.  She turns back to the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  I should dedicate this,  right? (thinks) This is for that special someone our  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden smiles.  Banky joins him.  Holden glances at him. Banky offers a mocking mimic of his smile. The band starts playing.  Cross cutting begins. Alyssa launches into a torchy tune.  The song is  extremely sexy - as is Alyssa who works the mic, making  direct eye contact with... Holden.  Or does she!  Holden is smiling, being seduced, Banky rolls his eyes.  Beside Holden, stands a pretty  GIRL with a short haircut, who's also riveted by Alyssa's performance. Alyssa makes big-time eye contact with somebody out  there.   The song seems to be aimed at whoever she's looking at.   It's more than obvious there's a seduction going on, bur  of whom!  At the end of the song, the crowd goes wild but Alyssa's preoccupied.  She points to someone in the  crowd, and curls her finger back in a 'c'mere' fashion,  urging whoever it is to join her.  She jumps off the  stage. Holden shakes his head sheepishly and looks downward, aw- shucks style.  At that moment, the Girl beside him leaps  forward.  Banky's eyes widen.  Holden looks up and is  suddenly taken aback. Alyssa and the Girl race into each other's arms and fall  into a way-to-passionate-to-mean-anything-else kiss. Holden's eyes bug.  Banky allows a smile to creep across  his face.  The crowd applauds.  Banky looks around, and  for the first time, we get the distinct impression that  this is a lesbian bar... There are a lot of chicks in this place.  Gay chicks.   Banky looks at Holden and slaps him on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that, my friend, is a.. (brings his fingers together,  mimicing Holden) ...shared moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden continues to stare - mouth agape. Alyssa and the Girl continue to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky, Holden, Alyssa and the Girl from the dance floor  sit around a table.  Alyssa and the Girl continue to make out.  Holden and Banky casually watch, wide-eyed.  Banky  stares a little harder.  Holden hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under his breath) That's rude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, when are we ever going to get a  chance to see this kind of shit live  without paying for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa and the Girl break their kiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh - better knock it off: we're  getting a man excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.  It's just... new to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and you're an old hand at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I should apologize.  I don't  usually get all mushy in public.  But  it's been awhile since I've seen Kim  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (formerly the Girl) Tell me you didn't set that gross  display up with the band just so you  could nail me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I'd have to go through that much  effort

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what!  I want to dance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.  I'll watch from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tugging at her arm) No.  I want to dance with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be such a rag.  I have to sit  here and work up the desire to fuck  you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kim exits.  Banky is smiling ear-to-ear.  Alyssa looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said 'fuck'.  To that girl.  You  said you'd 'fuck' her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can a girl 'fuck' another girl!  Were you talking about strap-ons or  something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hits him) Would you shut up!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What!!?  It's a valid question.  You  know the dyke stuff in the Penthouse  Letters section is written by guys -  this is our chance to get the inside  scoop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Alyssa) I don't know how many times I can  apologize for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.  Secretly, all I really  want is to be the center of attention. (to Banky) I've never used a snap-on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's with saying 'fuck?   Shouldn't you say 'eat her out' or at  least modify the term 'fuck' with  something like 'fist'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me ask you a question - can men  'fuck' each other!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ask Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your estimation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So for you, to 'fuck' means to  penetrate.  You're used to the more  traditional definition - you inside  some girl you've duped, jack-hammering  away, not noticing that bored look in  her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey - I always notice the bored look  in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) 'Fucking' is nor limited to  penetration, Banky. For me it  describes any sex when it's not  totally about love.  I don't love Kim,  but I'll fuck her.  I'm sure you don't  love every girl you sleep with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of them I downright loathe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'll bet it's different with the  ones you love.  I'll bet you go the  full nine when it's not just a quick  fix - like you go down on them longer  or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stopped dropping.  It got to be too  frustrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As stupid as you usually come off  during this diatribe of your's, you're  going to come off ten times as stupid  on this occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!  I lost my tolerance for the  bullshit baggage that comes with  eating girls out.  What's the big  deal?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you say the smell, so help me, I'll  slug you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Ah-ha! (to Holden) Now we're haggling.

dialogues.speaker: INT CAR
dialogues.text: It's drizzling outside.  Holden drives.  Alyssa hugs her  painting and pushes her bare feet against the windshield, making footprints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wondered what kind of  people buy those things.  I can't  believe you talked him down to twenty  five!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was looking shakey when he told me  the artist was a blind cripple with a  hump-back, but I held my ground.   There's no room for sympathy in the  buyer's market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going to hang it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not.  You are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to hang it for you?  You  better hope it doesn't get out to the  girl-nation that you needed a man to  help you hang a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to hang it in your house.   I bought it for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks at him) I'm serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's captured the moment.   It'll be a constant reminder - not  just of tonight, but of our  introduction, the building of our  friendship, everything.  Make no  mistake about it my Friend - it's a  gift to you, from me, so you'll always  remember us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden stares ahead.  Then he swerves the wheel to the  right.

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: The car pulls to the side of the road.  The rain is a bit heavier now.

dialogues.speaker: INT CAR
dialogues.text: Holden throws the car into park

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we stopping?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I can't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't take what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You love me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you.  And not in a friendly  way, although I think we're great  friends.  And not in a misplaced  affection, puppy-dog way, although I'm  sure that's what you'll call it.  And  it's not because you're unattainable.   I love you.  Very simple, very truly.   You're the epitome of every attribute  and quality I've ever looked for in  another person.  I know you think of  me as just a friend and crossing that  line is the furthest thing from an  option you'd ever consider.  But I  can't do this any longer.  I can't  stand next to you without wanting to  hold you.  I can't look into your eyes  without feeling that longing you only  read about in trashy romance novels.   I can't talk to you without wanting to  express my love for everything you  are.  I know this will probably queer  our friendship - no pun intended - but  I had to say it, because I've never  felt this before, and I like who I am  because of it.  And if bringing it to  light means we can't hang out anymore,  then that hurts me.  But I couldn't  allow another         day to go by without  getting it out there, regardless of  the outcome, which by the look on your  face is to be the inevitable shoot- down.  And I'll accept that But I know  some part of you is hesitating for a  moment, and if there is a moment of  hesitation, that means you feel  something too.  All I ask is that you  not suppress that - at least for ten  minutes - and try to dwell in it  before you dismiss it.   There isn't another soul on this  fucking planet who's ever made me the  person I am when I'm with you, and I  would risk this friendship for the  chance to take it to the next plateau.   Because it's there between you and me.   You can't deny that.  And even if we  never speak again after tonight,  please know that I'm forever changed  because of you and what you've meant  to me, which - while I do appreciate  it - I'd never need a painting of  birds bought at a diner to remind me  of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden stares at Alyssa.  She stares back.  Then she gets out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it something I said?

dialogues.speaker: EXT ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: Holden gets out of the car.  It's raining pretty hard  now.  Alyssa's hitching up the road.  Holden reaches her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back in the car and get out of  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to hitch to New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'ep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you at least going to comment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my comment fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was so unfair.  You know how  unfair that was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's unfair that I'm in love with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's unfortunate that you're in  love with me.  It's  unfair that you  felt the fucking need to unburden your  soul about it.  Do you remember for a  fucking second who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?  People change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's that simple?  You fall in  love with me and want a romantic  relationship, nothing changes for you  with the exception of feeling hunky- dorey all the time.  But what about- me?  It's not that simple, is it?  I  can't just get into a relationship  with you without throwing my whole  fucking world into upheaval!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that's every relationship!   There's always going to be a period of  adjustment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Period of adjustment?!? (hitting him) THERE'S NO 'PERIOD OF ADJUSTMENT'  HOLDEN!  I'M FUCKING GAY!  THAT'S WHO  I AM!  AND YOU ASSUME I CAN TURN THAT  AROUND JUST BECAUSE YOU'VE GOT A  CRUSH?!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this is a crush... then I don't  know if I could take the real thing if  it ever happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him, rain drenching the pair.  She shakes  her head ruefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home, Holden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She walks away.  Holden stands there, at a loss.  Then he turns and heads back to his car.   As he reaches the door and turns to look back at her,  Alyssa pounces on him, grabs his face and locks lips with him, big time.  He drops his keys and embraces her. And there they stand, by the side of the road, drenched  kissing.

dialogues.speaker: EXT STUDIO
dialogues.text: Banky carries a bag in one arm and pulls out his keys  with the other.  He jams them into the lock, opening the  door.  He picks up the mail on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: INT STUDIO
dialogues.text: He closes the door behind him and shuffles to the  kitchenette, passing by the blanket-covered, slumbering  forms of Holden and Alyssa, who are out cold in each  other's arms.  The place looks a mess - Like a couple of  people were engaged in some tremendous fucking.  Banky is oblivious.  He sets the bag down on the counter and pulls out a chocolate milk.  He opens it, sticks a straw into  the top, and begins sipping and sifting through the mail. He comes to mail that's Holden's and tosses it onto the  couch, near Holden's head.  He looks down at the sleeping couple, then back at the mail for a couple of beats.   Then he freezes.  He looks down again, and drops his jaw  and his carton of choco.  It hits the floor with a pop.   Holden and Alyssa shoot straight up, eyes struggling to  focus.  They look at one another, then at the  flabbergasted Banky.  Banky blinks.  Then he shuffles  toward the door again and lets himself out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off Holden's reaction) I take it that's not good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting up) Stay here. (he kisses her and exits)

dialogues.speaker: EXT STREET
dialogues.text: Banky sits on a curb, staring into the distance, Holden  saunters up and sits beside him.  He follows Banky's  gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catholic school girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street, the Catholic High School is letting  out.  Teenage girls clad in uniforms and tight sweaters  smoke, frolic, wait for their bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The uniform is what does it for me.  I  wish I'd have went with more Catholic  school girls when I was a kid.  As it  stands.  I have no "...and then she  unzipped her jumper..." stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You looked weirded out back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my couch you were fucking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to watch some TV.  Hard to do  when your best friend's wrapped around  a naked rug-muncher on your couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had boxers on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky shoots him a glare.  He goes back to staring at the OC girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is all going to end badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you.  You're way too  conservative for that girl.  She's  been around and seen things we've only  read about in books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we have read about them.  So we're  prepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no 'we' here.  You're going to  have to go through this alone.  And  it's one thing to read about shit, and  something different when you're forced  to deal with it on a regular basis.   When you guys are walking in the mall  and both your heads turn at a really  nice looking chick, it's going to eat  you up inside.  You'll spend most of  your time wondering when the other  shoe's going to drop.  Because for  you, this isn't about cool weird sex  stuff, it's about love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it is for her as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somehow I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone's not out to get someone in  life.  Bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody has an agenda.  Everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My agenda is to watch your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To what end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To insure that all this time we've  spent together, building something,  wasn't wasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not going to ruin the comic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't talking about the comic. (gets up) I'm going to gel a bagel.  Clean off  my fucking couch so I can watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky walks away.  Holden shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: INT ALYSSA'S LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: An all-girl gathering. TORY. NICA, DALIA and JANE help  Alyssa finish an issue of 'Idiosyncratic Routine'.  Tory  letters a page.  Nica and Dalia lay-out the artwork.   Dalia drinks wine.  Alyssa paints the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From what I understand, when you sign  with a publisher, someone else does  all this work for you, and you just  sit back and collect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And miss these last minute cram  sessions with my nearest and dearest?   Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what she's bitching  about.  All she's done since we got  here is pound Merlot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry weren't you the one who  misspelled 'receipt' on page eighteen?   Yeah, you're a real help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'd like to know is why we're  here at all when we haven't seen  Princess funny-Book in a month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah Alyssa - who've you been shacking  up with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Shacking up!' Please. (stops painting; smiles wide) I'm so in love!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone aww's.  Alyssa buries her face, giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  I know -I feel like such a  goon.  But I can't help it - we have  such a great time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is it?  Don't even tell me it's  Ms. Thing from the C.D. place.  I'll  kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not her.  It's someone you guys  don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That chick you left the restaurant  with that night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not.  From around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even tell me you met her down  the shore!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eww!  Not a bridge-and-tunnel Jersey  dyke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With huge hair and acid-washed jeans!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all cackle.  Alyssa tries to laugh with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Alyss - Hoboken Hussy or  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your information, they don't have  big hair or wear acid wash. (goes back to painting) They're from my home town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dalia stares at Alyssa, suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you playing the pronoun game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  What are you talking about?   I'm not even.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are. "I met someone."  "We have a  great time.  "They're from my home  town."  Doesn't this tube of wonderful have a name!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Holden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All four Girls stare at Alyssa, a bit horrified.  She  stops painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Alyssa - no.  Not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're dating a guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not like a typical man.  He's  really sweet to me, and we relate so  well.  You guys'd love him, really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at Alyssa.  Then Dalia gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've gotta go to the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They exit.  Alyssa looks to Tory and Nica.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pouring wine) Whelp - here's to both of you. (moves the glass to her lips) Another one bites the dust.

dialogues.speaker: INT HOLDEN'S BEDROOM -NIGHT
dialogues.text: Holden and Alyssa lie in each other's arms, moonlight  bathing them.  She smokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even tell me you want to do it  again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why me - you know?  Why now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you were giving me that look,  and I got wet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a guy.  You're attracted to girls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see you've been taking notes.  Historically, yes  that's true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given that a lot of thought, you  know?  I mean, now that I'm being  ostracized by my friends, I've had a  lot of time to think about all of  this.  And what I've come up with is  really simple: I came to this on my  terms.  I didn't just heed what I was  taught, you  know?  Men and women  should be together, it's the natural  way - that kind of thing.  I'm not  with you because of what family,  society, life tried to instill in me  from day one.  The way the world is -  how seldom you meet that one person  who gets you... it's so rare.   My  parents didn't really have it.  There  was no example set for me in the world  of male/female relation ships.  And to  cut oneself off from finding that  person - to immediately half your  options by eliminating the possibility  of finding that one person within your  own gender... that just seemed stupid.   So I didn't.  And by leaving my  options open, I was branded 'gay',  which to me was no big deal - labels  are labels, you know?  They define  what you do, not who you are, I guess.  But                 then you come along.  You -  the one least likely; I mean, you were  a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while I was falling for you, I put  a ceiling on that, because you were a  guy.   Until I remembered why I opened the  door to women in the first place - to  not limit the likelihood of finding  that one person who'd compliment me so  completely.  And so here we are, I was  thorough when I looked for you, and I  feel justified lying in your arms -  because I got here on my terms, and  have no question that there was  someplace I didn't look.  And that  makes all the difference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you took the luster our of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What luster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (joking - in case you didn't  get it) Of how I brought you back from the  other side.  How all you needed was  the right man to turn you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not the right man. (kisses him) You're just the one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snuggles into him and closes her eyes.  Holden stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I at least cell people that all  you needed was some serious deep- dicking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hits him with her pillow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1) In Holden's Apartment - Alyssa waves in various  directions, shaking her head accordingly.  Then she puts  up her hands to stop.  Cut to Holden, hanging the  picture.  Alyssa gave him.   It hangs at a severely crooked angle.  He looks back to  her and shakes his head 'no'. 2) Holden and Alyssa try to play a video game.  Banky  plays as well.  Holden instructs her in the ways of NHL  '96 (turning her paddle right-side-up, pointing at things on the screen).  She presses the reset button, over and  over.  Banky gives Holden a 'What the fuck?' look.   Alyssa sticks her tongue at him. 3) At the Video Store - Holden picks up a Disney cartoon  off the shelf.  He goes to show if to Alyssa, who's  reading the back of 'Anything But Dick', an allchick  porno.  An old WOMAN stares at her.  Holden nods to the  old Woman and takes the tape out of Alyssa's hands,  putting it back on the shelf.  He ushers her away.  The  old Woman waits until they're gone and then picks up the  tape herself, 4) Holden carries Alyssa on his shoulders through the  park, her crotch against the back of his neck.  He's  talking. She taps him and he stops and looks up.  She  begins to maneuver around so her crotch is in his face.   He pulls her off and put her down.  She's laughing.  He's flushed with embarrassment.  The same Old Woman from the  Video store passes by with her husband.  Holden shrugs. 5) In Holden's Apartment again - Alyssa again with the  waving, then putting up her hands to stop.  Cut to Holden again, this time with the painting hung completely upside down.  He looks at it, then offers her a bewildered gaze. 6) In the Office Banky comes to his drawing table.  There are penciled pages on it with a note that says "Hanging  out with Alyssa today.  Holden".  Banky crumples it up  and throws it across the room. 7) In Holden's Apartment - Alyssa waves this way, then  that way, then puts up her hands frantically to stop.   She settles back against the wall, a satisfied smile  crawling across her face, and closes her eyes.  We pull  back to reveal Holden on his knees in front of her,  eating her out (no, we don't see anything!).

dialogues.speaker: INT OFFICE
dialogues.text: Holden draws.  A book is thrown in front of him.  He  looks up.  Banky stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check out page forty eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden looks down at that book.  It's the Nineteen Eighty Eight yearbook from Middletown North.  He shakes his head at Banky and flips it open. On the page is Alyssa's Senior year photo.  Under her  name is another name in quotes that says 'Finger Cuffs'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see the nickname?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Finger Cuffs'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... she had a weird nick-name.   What's your point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know why it's 'Finger Cuffs'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. (takes a seat) You remember Cohee Lundin?  Left  Hudson and went to North our senior  year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ran into him at Food City the  other day, and we got to talking, and  I mentioned that you were dating  Alyssa, and he said..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO COHEE LUNDON.  In the PARKING LOT of FOOD CITY,  addressing the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alyssa Jones?  Shit.  I know Alyssa  Jones.  I mean, I know Alyssa Jones,  you know what I'm saying?   Me and Rick Derris used to hang our  with her for awhile, right?  Just  hanging around her house after school,   'cuz her parents were like never home,  and shit.  And one day, Rick just  whips it out, and starts rubbing it on  her leg and shit; chasing her around  the living room - I was dying.  But  you know what the crazy bitch did?   She fucking drops to her knees, and  just starts sucking him off right in  front of me!  Like I wasn't even there  man!  I almost died!  But that's not  the fucked up part - the fucked up  part was Rick, man - right in the  middle of it, he turns to me and he's  pointing at her and he says "Cohee."   Just like that - "Cohee."  So I'm like  I'll give it a shot.  And I start  pulling her pants down all slow, 'cuz  I figure any second she's gonna turn  around and belt me in the mouth,  right?  But yo, check this shit out -  she's all into it man!  She don't try  to stop me or nothing!  She's                  all wet and shit, and I just went to  work, know what I'm saying?  Me and  Rick are going to town on this crazy  bitch, and she's just loving it, all  moaning and shit!  It was fucked up!   So Rick's the one that came up with  the nickname - 'cuz that day, she had  us locked in tight from both sides -  like a pair of goddamn Chinese finger  cuffs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK IN THE OFFICE - Holden stares at Banky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cohee's a lot of things, but an  exxagerator he's not.  The dude's  Catholic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's never even been with a guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what she says.  But I say her  on her hands and knees getting filled  out like an application constitutes  'being with a guy'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's pulling your chain.  And the fact  that you even bought it for a second  makes you look like an idiot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting your back, asshole!   People don't forget shit like 'Finger  Cuffs'.  And if it got out that she's  queer as well, how do you think it's  going to make you look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give a shit what people think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, forget about that; what if  she's carrying a disease?  That was  just one story - what if there's more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs his coat) You're such a fucking asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Oh, it's not possible that  she's all crudded up?  Cohee I can  vouch for as clean - the dude never  got laid in high school.  But Derris  is an arch fucking bush-man!  Name me  one chick in our senior class that  Rick Derris didn't nail, for Christ's  sake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you let this go?  I'm telling  you - she's never even been with a  guy, let alone those two zeroes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm telling you, the bitch could  be a bigger fucking germ farm than  that monkey in 'Outbreak'!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holden grabs Banky and pins him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it a rest!  Do you hear me?!  I'm  tired of this shit!  She's my goddamn  girlfriend, do you understand?!  Show  her a little fucking respect!   And if you ever even so much as  mention that Alyssa looks a little  peaked from now on, I'll put your  fucking teeth down your throat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He releases Banky.  Banky brushes himself off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll put your fucking teeth down  your throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking out) Not bloody Likely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banky runs to the open door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling after him) I've been working out you know! (no response) You better be ready to make that M-TV  deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The downstairs door slams.  Banky makes a muscle, then  feels it.

dialogues.speaker: INT TOWER RECORDS
dialogues.text: Holden and Hooper peruse laser discs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's that bitch partner of your's  been?
